g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
Building on the frameworks for identifying market failures (Section 16.2) and systemic failures (Section
16.3) in the innovation system for climate
it considers some of the policy instruments introduced in Chapter 13 that are particularly relevant for
the pace and direction of innovation in technologies for climate change mitigation and adaptation.
explains why governments put in place policies to promote innovation in climate related
technologies. Third, it takes stock of the overall empirical and theoretical evidence regarding the
relationship between policy instruments with a direct and an indirec
(including intellectual property regimes) and also other outcomes (competitiveness and distributional
outcomes). Fourth, it assesses the evidence on the impact of trade
This section focuses on innovation policies and institutions which are implemented at the national level.
Whenever relevant, this section highlights examples of policies or initiatives that delve more deeply
level sectors: power, transport, industry, buildings, and AFOLU. Whenever possible,
this section also discusses issues in policy selection, design, and implementation that have been
identified as more relevant in developing countries and emergin
Overall, this section shows that national and subnational policies and institutions are one of the main
factors determining the redirection and acceleration of technological innovation and low

training, R&D) and demand pull (e.g., economic and fiscal support and regulatory policy instruments),

). The evidence on procurement is generally

when it comes to the competitiveness outcome (at least in the short term) is more mixed.

Government policies can influence changes in technologies, as well as changes to the systems they
uments stimulate innovation by increasing the supply of new knowledge
through funding and performing research; increasing the supply of trained scientists and engineers
